Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A Sociolinguistic Analysis of How Cooperation Emerges in Multiethnic Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Anthropologists have long established that social cohesion and enduring interpersonal relationships can be difficult to establish in dynamic multiethnic and multicultural environments. When they are not, the consequences can be adverse: contexts marked by poorly formed social relationships can correlate to interethnic conflict. Conversely, social cohesion and cooperation among diverse individuals and groups can have positive social impacts (for example, such contexts can become important trade centers). This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous scientific fieldwork in the study of language and culture, asks what linguistic anthropological evidence exists to explain how cooperation between linguistically and culturally diverse individuals and groups emerges.

Mr. Nikolas Sweet under the supervision of Dr. Judith Irvine of the University of Michigan will how explore interpersonal relationships are formed in heteroglossic, dynamic contexts. This project questions what sociolinguistic evidence exists to explain how cooperation and cohesion is achieved among diverse individuals and groups. The research takes place in a formerly marginalized region in Senegal on the Guinea border, a context once characterized by interethnic conflict which has now become the site of significant trade, transportation, artisanal gold mining, and in-migration from all across Senegal and West Africa. As such, it is a novel site for a sociolinguistic study of how multilingual speakers from diverse backgrounds develop interpersonal relationships. This is a two-phase project that compares a rural context and large regional center, with the aim of exploring differences in the communicative practices between urban and rural centers, and how access to trade networks impacts language use. Through an in-depth study of face-to-face conversations in multiple languages between differentially positioned individuals, this project will be able to investigate how ethnic and national associations--categories that are too often taken for granted--are in fact negotiated in verbal interactions. Finally, this project contributes to understandings of how proximity to national borders affects individuals' linguistic practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined how people in southeastern Senegal negotiate relationships between each other through practices of casual joking, story telling, and the giving of respect and disrespect. It found that looking at these verbal genres in the region requires an attention to both rural villages where as well as the larger towns where members of rural communities inceasingly search out economic opportunities. Rural areas were perceived often as cultural-homelands, where individuals learned the true and deep ways of speaking as well as holding onto authentic culture. Young children, for example, learn how to speak like adults as part of initiation ceremonites still practiced in rural communities. At the same time, they engage in marriage joking, teasing out potential partners in their broader communities. Teasing, in many ways tests individuals as to the status of their relationship with you, and can potentially help reap rewards. Trips to other parts of the region allow individuals searching employment to learn other languages and ways of speaking that, if successfully performed, can give them increased resect and prestige within their home communities. Such attempts at performing world savvy street wise, howerver, can also fail. Participants were creative and bent the taken-for-granted rules about how individuals are supposed to talk to their benefit. However, at other times, puns, sayings, and shared naming connections reveal a shared tendency to express relationships in the world in common ways. Communities collectively assessed the moral world of the gold mining economy by sharing mining stories and working out ethics in casual conversations.

As regards institutionalized joking, this study concludes that any attempts to analyze ethnic or other group as corporate blocks without attention to how individuals can position themselves strategically is doomed to essentialism. For example, while certain last names are commonly agreed to be members in a relationship of institutionalized joking, participants can easily take the name of a partner or relative, or deny such a connection. However, looking in a detailed way at stereotypes (or in a less negative light, how people negotiate generalizations) is of central importance in exploring how individuals negotiate themselves in relationship to the world.
